author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Zuckerberg Apologizes for Facebook Data Handling
text:
0 COMMENTS Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg testifies Tuesday at a congressional hearing in Washington, D.C. Photo: Win McNamee/POOL/EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
A man was sentenced to 37 months in federal prison for making threats to a witness in the bribery and corruption case involving Atlanta’s city government and contractors. (AJC, FOX5)
Courts in South Korea offered three different estimates of the amount of bribes taken by the country’s former president, Park Geun-hye, who awaits sentencing. Both sides are expected to appeal the decision to convict the former president on some counts of corruption, but to acquit her on other charges. (Hankyoreh, Hankyoreh)
Two police officers in South Africa were arrested for alleged bribery and corruption. The article didn’t contain comments from the officers. (Enca)
Money Laundering:
Europol said it arrested 11 people it says are part of a drug-trafficking ring that laundered money from Spain to Colombia by using cryptocurrencies and credit cards. The article didn’t include responses from the suspects. (CD)
Prosecutors charged seven people from classified-ad website Backdoor.com with prostitution, conspiracy and money laundering. The article didn’t contain comments from any of the people charged. Federal authorities seized the website last week. (CNN, Hill)
A New Jersey chiropractor pleaded guilty to laundering money through his family’s Russian bank accounts. (APP)
Officials in New Zealand accused a company there of failing to adhere to anti-money laundering and terrorism-financing laws. A company director is expected to testify. (NZH)
Authorities in the U.K. have yet to arrest any of the six people charged in a share-price manipulation and money-laundering scheme. (Times)
Cybercrime:
Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg went before Congress on Tuesday to apologize for allowing the data of tens of millions of the site’s users to be improperly accessed by third parties. (CNN)
Government officials in Australia are promising to improve cybersecurity to better protect against online crime. (SMH)
Kenya says cybercrime cost the country 21 billion shillings, or $207.7 million, last year. (KBC)
Sanctions:
Russia says it will work to mitigate the consequences of new U.S. sanctions on the country, and just needs some time to adjust to the changes. The latest sanctions could cost Russian oligarchs up to $16 billion. Ukraine said it will place sanctions on Russian oligarchs. People looking to invest in Russia do so at their own risk . (Reuters, NBC, Reuters, CNBC)
The U.S. said Tuesday it supports efforts by some European nations to impose additional sanctions on Iran. (Reuters)
Whistleblowers:
Could the arrest of an FBI agent for allegedly sharing classified information with a reporter cause other reporters and whistleblowers to hold back before approaching the agency? (WP)
A defense of whistleblowers and their importance to democracy is here . (LAT)
General Anticorruption:
The home and offices of Michael Cohen, the personal attorney for U.S. President Donald Trump, were raided by federal agents. Investigators seized documents related to alleged payments made to two women who say they had sexual relationships with Mr. Trump. The president took to Twitter to express his displeasure. (WP, NYT, CNN)
A payment from a Ukrainian businessman to the foundation of U.S. President Donald Trump is drawing interest from the special prosecutor’s office. (NYT)
A Virginia man pleaded guilty to child pornography in a case in which he paid women in the Philippines to sexually abuse children. (release)
The latest in a series of reports on corruption and power in Russia is released. (FPRI)
Opposition lawmakers in South Korea want the newly appointed head of the Financial Supervisory Service to resign after reports he took foreign trips paid for by banks while he was a legislator. The official apologized for the controversy, while the president’s office said the travel was legitimate. (UPI)
